benchmark_details.name: UnsafeBench
benchmark_details.overview: UnsafeBench is a benchmarking framework that evaluates the effectiveness and robustness of image safety classifiers on real-world and AI-generated images. It consists of a dataset of 10K annotated images across 11 unsafe categories to support the evaluation of various classifiers.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a comprehensive evaluation framework for image safety classifiers, focusing on their effectiveness and robustness against real-world and AI-generated unsafe images.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The dataset may contain challenges as all images are queried using a common set of unsafe keywords, making them difficult to classify for image safety classifiers.

data.source: UnsafeBench dataset consists of 10K images curated from large databases including LAION-5B and Lexica, annotated for safety and categorization.
data.annotation: Annotated by three authors of the paper.

methodology.calculation: F1 Score is used to evaluate the effectiveness of image safety classifiers, measuring precision and recall across 11 unsafe categories.
methodology.interpretation: An F1 Score closer to 1 indicates better classifier performance, while lower scores suggest poorer effectiveness.
methodology.baseline_results: Baseline F1 Scores vary among classifiers; GPT-4V achieves high scores in multiple categories.
methodology.validation: The UnsafeBench dataset has been validated through human annotation and computing agreement statistics.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: Measures include restricting exposure of annotators to harmful images, with an ethical review approved by an institution's Ethics Review Board.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: All annotations were manually performed by authors, avoiding exposure of distressing content to external annotators.
